lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen and identify key details about two twins and the different jobs they try by choosing correct answers (e.g., circle the correct answer).
supportStrategies: (Listening) Play a segment from the video. Ask: “Who is trying the job?” “What job is it?” Students circle or tick answers in their SB.
stretchStrategies: Job Skills Match-Up – After watching the video, stronger students match each job to a skill and explain why.
E.g., Firefighters need to be brave. Teachers need to be kind and smart.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say how animals in the video are similar to or different from animals near their homes.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Ask: “What jobs do people do near your home?” Compare with the jobs in the video using a T-chart.
stretchStrategies: Job Skills Match-Up – After watching the video, stronger students match each job to a skill and explain why.
E.g., Firefighters need to be brave. Teachers need to be kind and smart.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can discuss what people do in different jobs and name some skills needed for those jobs.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Critical Thinking) Brainstorm: “What skills does a vet need?” “What skills does a firefighter need?” Students match skills to jobs on the board.
stretchStrategies: Job Skills Match-Up – After watching the video, stronger students match each job to a skill and explain why.
E.g., Firefighters need to be brave. Teachers need to be kind and smart.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
